sections.title: Module Credit and Completion Requirements and Learning Objective
sections.body:
Credit and Completion Requirements

To successfully earn credit and meet the learning objectives of this Web-Based Learning Application, it is essential to engage with every page, complete all knowledge checks, and complete the initial and final assessment independently. The assessment will require a 70% passing rate and while you are encouraged to refer to your notes of the course content during the assessment, any form of cheating is discouraged. Please also note that this course will expire by April 25, 2025.

Module Learning Objectives

Upon successful completion of the course, you will be able to:

  • Define project risk and identify various types of risks that may occur in a project.
  • Recognize the risk management process and explore tools and frameworks relevant to each step of the process.
  • Gain a full understanding of Quality Assurance and its benefits and importance in managing digital transformation projects, specifically in the Risk Monitoring phase.
  • Obtain knowledge on the existing Philippine regulations in risk management systems to get ahead of identifying and monitoring possible risks in projects.

sections.title: Project Risk Management Lessons
sections.body:
Learning Objective

At the end of this lesson, you will be able to:
  • Define project risk and identify various types of risks that may occur in a project.

sections.title: Overview of Risk
sections.col1:
• An unpredictable event or situation that, if it happens, can positively or negatively impact the goals of a project.
  • Project risks can have positive outcomes, referred to as opportunities, or they can result in negative or unfavorable consequences, known as threats.

sections.title: Overview of Risk
sections.col1:
Internal Risk

Internal risks are those that may come from the organization. Project analysts must identify and prioritize these types of risks.

Types of Internal Risks
  • Schedule Risk - The risk of activities taking longer than expected can lead to schedule delays, increased costs, and the postponement of project benefits, potentially causing a loss of competitive advantage.
  • Resource Risk - Outsourcing and personnel-related risks, such as high attrition rates, can slow down progress in large projects with many employees. Introducing new resources late in the project can further hinder progress and affect timelines.
  • Budget Risk - Budget risks involve the escalation of project costs due to inaccurate cost estimations and scope creep.
  • Performance Risk - The risk that a completed project may not perform as intended or fail to meet the business requirements that justified its initiation.
  • Scope Risk - Scope risks encompass changes in scope, often resulting from scope creep.
  • Quality Risk - Quality risks may arise if the product or project lacks clear acceptance criteria or fails to meet customer needs.
  • Technical Risk - Technology failures, such as security incidents or service outages, can disrupt operations and impact business continuity, especially when new technology does not meet expectations. For instance, an e-commerce platform crash could result in lost revenue, while poor implementation or process issues in procurement, production, or distribution could further complicate operations.
sections.col2:
External Risk

External risks are beyond the control of the project team and the organization hosting the project. These risks are typically harder to foresee and manage.

Types of External Risks
  • Strategic Risk - Risks associated with failed business decisions or indecision that may impact a company. These risks can lead to potential losses from pursuing an unsuccessful business plan. For example, selecting a technology for a project that ultimately cannot be made to work.
  • Environmental Risk - This risk arises from the potential for business activities to alter the status quo due to specific events. Examples include delays in obtaining legislative approvals from authorized agencies, projects located in coastal zones, negative community impacts, and natural disasters such as earthquakes, hurricanes, or volcanic eruptions.
  • Market Risk - Market risks are the potential for an organization to incur losses due to factors that impact the overall performance of financial markets.
  • Legal Risk - Potential losses stemming from the unpredictability of legal proceedings, such as bankruptcy or impending litigation.
sections.col3:
Other Type of Risks

Project managers must comprehend cybersecurity risks to safeguard their projects from cyberattacks. Below are some key cybersecurity risks to be mindful of.

  • Data breaches - Data breaches are among the most prevalent cybersecurity threats. In 2022, over 6.5 billion data records were exposed due to data breaches.
  • Phishing - Phishing remains a major threat, with cybercriminals using deceptive emails, text messages, or websites to trick customers or employees into disclosing sensitive information like passwords or account numbers. This stolen data can lead to financial theft, identity fraud, or unauthorized access to the organization’s internal systems.
  • Insider threats - Insider threats, from disgruntled employees or third-party vendors, pose significant cybersecurity risks by intentionally or unintentionally leaking sensitive data or creating vulnerabilities for external hackers.
  • Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) Attacks - DDoS attacks overwhelm a bank’s online services with excessive traffic, causing slowdowns, crashes, and service unavailability, disrupting operations and potentially exposing systems to further exploitation.
  • Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) - APTs are advanced attacks where cybercriminals gain unauthorized access to a bank’s network, quietly monitoring systems and stealing data over time, often remaining undetected for months allowing hackers to extract valuable information.
  • Third-party risk - Some companies rely on third-party vendors for services like cloud storage and payment processing, but these vendors can become weak links in a company’s cybersecurity, with cyberattacks on them creating backdoors for hackers to access sensitive data.
  • Compliance violations - Compliance violations can result in fines and other penalties. It is crucial to ensure that your organization and digitalization projects adhere to all applicable regulations.

sections.title: Project Risk Management Lessons
sections.body:
Learning Objective

At the end of this lesson, you will be able to:
  • Recognize the risk management process and explore tools and frameworks relevant to each step of the process.

sections.title: Risk Management
sections.col1:
• This encompasses the processes involved in planning, identifying, analyzing, responding to, and monitoring and controlling risks within a project.
  • The objectives are to enhance the likelihood and impact of positive events while reducing the probability and impact of adverse events affecting the project.

sections.title: Risk Management
sections.subheader: Four Phases of Risk Management Process
sections.body:
The risk management process is comprised of four phases, as depicted in the following diagram: Identification, Assessment, Handling, and Monitoring

Risk Identification

Risk identification involves analyzing project areas and key processes to pinpoint potential issues, hazards, and threats that could affect progress. Methods for identifying risks include reviewing the work breakdown structure, conducting expert interviews, analyzing past lessons, examining design specifications, and evaluating project strategies. Regular risk assessments and management reviews also help identify and address risks.

Risk Assessment

Risk assessment involves evaluating identified risks and prioritizing them based on their potential impact on project goals. The project team analyzes each risk to determine its cause and effects, then rates them according to the likelihood of occurrence and the severity of their impact on cost, schedule, and technical performance.

Risk Handling

Risk handling involves identifying, evaluating, and selecting strategies to manage risks within acceptable levels, while considering project constraints and objectives. This process defines specific actions, timelines, responsible parties, and associated costs. The chosen strategy is based on the overall risk assessment rating.

Risk Monitoring

Risk monitoring involves tracking and assessing the effectiveness of risk-handling actions throughout the project, while developing additional strategies as needed. The team regularly monitors both the risks and the outcomes of these actions. A Risk Register is used to track activities, and high-level risks are included in the Monthly Project Status Report and discussed during Steering Committee meetings.

sections.title: Risk Identification
sections.col1:
RAID

Risks

A risk is defined as a potential future threat to the overall success of a project or any of its components. Each risk is associated with a likelihood and a corresponding severity rating.

Assumptions

Any factors that you assume will be in place and contribute to the successful outcome of your project.

An assumption is a statement accepted as fact. Assumptions must be validated.

Issues

An issue is an immediate, formally defined concern that requires action. It hinders the progress of a Workstream or the Program and lacks an agreed-upon resolution.

Dependencies

Dependencies are relationships between products or tasks. For instance, one product may consist of several other “dependent” products, or a task may not commence until a “dependent” task is completed.
sections.col2:
RAID Log

Utilizing a RAID log, or a similar tool, assists the PMO or Project Manager in capturing, organizing, prioritizing, and documenting the risks, assumptions, issues, and dependencies encountered during project planning and execution.

Raid log entries should be:

Specific, thoroughly identified, explained, and supported with references. They must be reviewed regularly to account for any changes in circumstances. Assumptions and dependencies should be validated throughout the project, as they may no longer hold true. Focus should be on defined high-impact, high-probability risks, each with clear ownership and next steps. When needed, items should be escalated using the appropriate escalation protocol, managed by the PMO and governance processes.

sections.title: Risk Identification
sections.col1: A risk register is a key tool in risk management, used to identify, analyze, and address potential setbacks in a project before they become issues. As outlined in the PMBOK guide, it records the results of risk analysis and response plans, with the initial entries coming from the risk identification process. The register details each identified risk, including descriptions, categories, causes, probabilities, potential responses, and responsible parties, making it a crucial component of the project management plan.

sections.title: Risk Identification
sections.col1:
Risk Register Components

Risk Identification

A risk identification field should include the following details to track and manage the risk effectively:

  • Risk name
  • Identification date
  • Subtitle (if needed)
Risk Description

After identifying the risk, add a brief description to the log. The description should include a short high-level overview of the risk, explain why it's a potential issue, and remain concise, typically 80 to 100 characters, providing enough detail for clear identification without overcomplicating it.

Risk Category

Quickly identifying the risk allows for prompt assignment to the appropriate team, especially in complex projects. Possible risk categories include Operations, Budget, Schedule, Technology, Information, Security, Quality, and Project Plan. To determine the category, evaluate the risk source and identify who can help resolve it. You may consult with department heads if the solution isn’t immediately clear.

Risk likelihood

The likelihood of a risk occurring is documented using simple categories: Not likely, Likely, and Very likely. Categorizing risks by likelihood helps prioritize which risks require immediate attention and which can be deferred.
sections.col2:
Risk analysis

Risk analysis evaluates the potential impact of a risk on a project, using a simple five-point scale (very low to very high) to assess severity. Prioritization, which considers both likelihood and impact, can be clarified by consulting with a department head if needed.

Risk Mitigation

A mitigation plan, or risk response plan, is essential in a risk register, aiming to identify and reduce potential risks. It should include a step-by-step solution to lessen the risk, a brief description of the intended outcome, and how the plan will affect the risk's impact.

Risk Priority

Risk priority should be based on both the likelihood and impact of the risk, helping to identify which risks may have the most harmful consequences. Priority can be documented using a simple number scale: 1 (Low), 2 (Medium), and 3 (High).

Risk ownership

The individual responsible for managing the risk and implementing the prevention or contingency plans. Risk owners can include stakeholders, members of the project team, the project manager, and the project sponsor.

Risk Status

The risk status field indicates whether a risk has been successfully mitigated or not. It can be filled out with the following options: Open, In progress, or Closed, or a more detailed list such as active, not started, on hold, ongoing, and complete.

sections.title: Risk Assessment
sections.body:
A Probability and Risk Matrix is a grid used to map the likelihood of each risk occurring and its impact on project objectives if it does occur. This matrix specifies combinations of probability and impact, allowing individual project risks to be categorized into priority groups. By using the probability and impact matrix, risks are classified as low, medium, or high based on two distinct factors: the overall probability of occurrence and the presumed impact if it occurs.

Impact

Impact is evaluated based on the extent of changes to the work plan (timing), cost, and quality if the risk materializes.

Probability

Probability measures the likelihood that the risk will materialize.

sections.title: Risk Handling
sections.subheader: Potential strategies to deal with risk
sections.col1:
Avoid

Risk avoidance is a strategy where the project team takes action to eliminate a threat or shield the project from its impact, often by modifying the Project Management plan. The project manager may isolate objectives from the risk, altering objectives by extending the schedule, changing the strategy, or reducing the scope. In extreme cases, the project may be shut down, while early risks can be avoided through clarified requirements, better communication, or acquiring expertise.

Mitigate

Risk mitigation is a strategy to reduce the likelihood or impact of a risk by lowering its probability and/or impact to acceptable levels. Early actions, such as simplifying processes, conducting additional tests, or selecting reliable suppliers, are often more effective than addressing damage after the risk occurs. If reducing probability is not possible, mitigation may focus on addressing the risk's impact, such as designing redundancy to lessen the impact of a system failure.
sections.col2:
Transfer

Risk transfer is a strategy where the project team shifts the impact of a threat to a third party, along with the responsibility for managing it. While it doesn't eliminate the risk, it assigns the management responsibility to another party, typically through tools like insurance, performance bonds, or contracts. This strategy is particularly effective for managing financial risks and can involve agreements that transfer liability, such as cost-plus or fixed-price contracts.

Accept

Risk acceptance is a strategy where the project team acknowledges a risk and takes no action unless it materializes, typically when addressing the risk is not feasible or cost-effective. This approach can be passive, involving no action other than documentation, or active, such as creating a contingency reserve with allocated time, money, or resources to manage the risk if it occurs.

Learning Objective

At the end of this lesson, you will be able to:
  • Gain a full understanding of Quality Assurance and its benefits and importance in managing digital transformation projects, specifically in the Risk Monitoring phase.

sections.title: Quality Assurance
sections.col1:
• Quality assurance in project management involves implementing a set of actions aimed at ensuring that the project’s final outcomes align with the expected requirements. It focuses on the processes that teams utilize to maintain standards and deliver quality results.
  • This can be regarded as an added layer to conduct Risk Monitoring in projects.

sections.title: Quality Assurance
sections.col1:
International Organization for Standardization (ISO)

The International Organization for Standardization (ISO) is an independent, non-governmental organization that develops guidelines for products, services, and systems to ensure quality, safety, and efficiency. Its globally recognized standards, including the ISO 9000 family, are adopted by businesses, governments, and organizations to establish uniformity and compliance across various sectors.

ISO maintains a family of quality management standards collectively known as the ISO 9000.

ISO defines quality as the degree to which an object's inherent characteristics fulfill the project requirements, which are linked to the project's scope. Effective quality management ensures deliverables meet the agreed-upon expectations, neither exceeding nor falling short of them.
sections.col2:
Good quality management must address:

Quality of the Project

Pushing the team too hard to meet requirements can result in lower profits, higher risks, employee attrition, errors, and extra rework. Therefore, the process of creating the product is just as important as the product itself.

Quality of the Product

Upon the product’s availability, ask yourself:

  • Does the deliverable fulfill the requirements agreed upon during scope definition?
  • If there is variations, is it acceptable?
  • Is it ready for use, and does it satisfy stakeholder expectations?

sections.title: Quality Assurance
sections.col1:
Total Quality Management

  • A strategy focused on continuous improvement
  • Every employee in the company is accountable for maintaining quality
  • Defines ‘quality’ based on customer requirements
sections.col2:
Sample Quality Initiatives for Continuous Improvement

Lean Manufacturing

Employs a method of eliminating waste and improving value.

Six Sigma

The Six Sigma standard, introduced by Bill Smith of Motorola, allows only 3.4 defects per million units. This technique is well-suited for manufacturing environments with large-scale production.

Malcom Bridge Award

The Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Award recognizes US organizations for performance excellence.

Deming Prize

One of the highest awards for total quality management in the world. It recognizes businesses that have successfully implemented total quality management in their processes.

sections.title: Benefits of QA in Project Management
sections.col1:
• Increase efficiency - Adopting QA standards throughout the project helps the team clearly understand quality requirements, resulting in improved efficiency.
  • Ensure customer satisfaction - Implementing QA processes ensures project teams deliver high-quality, error-free outcomes, leading to guaranteed customer satisfaction upon release.
  • Boost team morale - When team members understand QA standards at each project stage, it boosts their motivation, confidence, and overall morale.
  • Make continuous improvements - QA methods allow project managers to focus on continuously improving processes to uphold quality standards.
sections.col2:
Pitfalls that can be avoided with a proactive approach to QA

  • Lack of skilled QA resources - Assigning testing tasks to inexperienced business resources can result in ineffective testing, so QA staff must evaluate new testing technologies and gather necessary requirements before implementation.
  • Over-investing in Technology - The QA needs of small banks differ from large institutions, and while automation may be effective for some, it isn't a one-size-fits-all solution and can be costly for others.
  • Lack of Readiness - This risk assumes organizations can delay adding QA resources and involvement early in a project, but planning should account for contractual negotiations and third-party vendor onboarding timing.
  • Underestimating the Effort - All QA management activities, such as test planning, obtaining approvals, writing test cases, executing tests, and fixing defects, must be incorporated into any significant endeavor.
  • Inexperienced Leadership - QA executives should recognize that not all testing resources have the same skill set and must understand the specific talents required for frontline QA managers, whether focusing on process expertise or testing skills.
  • Do-it-yourself syndrome - QA teams should leverage the subject matter expertise of business users and avoid making decisions in isolation, instead seeking consensus and securing their support.
  • Over-engineering the Effort - Over-testing can lead to inflated costs and wasted time. The key criterion for testing is the value that the initiative delivers.

sections.title: Importance of QA in Digital Transformation Project
sections.col1:
• To build an effective QA team, form a trusted group with key roles like project management, technical leads, business leads, and business analysts. Hire a skilled QA lead or manager, either internally or externally, who fits your bank’s specific needs. Evaluate the necessary qualifications for your QA team, ensuring that business analysts and technical experts are not solely relied upon for QA tasks.
  • Next, determine the scope of the QA efforts and assess the tools and resources required to support the practice. Identify the training needs for the team and ensure the QA process and methodology align with your organization’s goals. Lastly, establish clear communication channels to maintain smooth coordination across all teams involved in the QA process.

sections.title: Importance of QA in Digital Transformation Project
sections.col1:
Integration Efforts

The rapid advancement of API technology, which often involves real-time integration, requires strong QA management to conduct thorough end-to-end testing whenever changes occur in your bank’s technology ecosystem. A strong QA practice provides the necessary oversight and discipline to ensure that newly combined solutions are adequately tested.

As APIs and open banking continue to gain momentum in financial institutions, the demand for high-quality solutions is more evident than ever. The rapid growth of API technology requires a comprehensive approach to ensure top-notch quality standards are maintained, especially in the fast-evolving open banking space. With real-time integrations and constant changes to your bank's technology ecosystem, strong QA management is essential for thorough end-to-end testing. A robust QA practice ensures that newly integrated solutions receive the necessary oversight and attention to meet the highest standards.

sections.title: Importance of QA in Digital Transformation Project
sections.col1:
New Software Releases

All software releases carry the risk of downtime. Prior to these scheduled events, it is essential for you and your stakeholders to assess the potential impact of a given release on revenue and production stability. Your assessment should be based on accurate QA data.

Deploying new software and solutions should never be a high-risk activity for your financial institution. Customized products and solutions unique to your bank must be thoroughly tested before deployment into the production environment. For FIS product releases, a strong QA practice is crucial to test not only the core solution but also any integrated third-party solutions. Every software release carries the risk of downtime, so prior to these events, you and your stakeholders need to assess the potential impact on revenue and production stability, ensuring decisions are based on accurate QA data.

sections.title: Importance of QA in Digital Transformation Project
sections.col1:
To establish a quality methodology, adopting standards like ISO 9001 helps create a best-practice framework ensuring customer requirements are met before product delivery. This approach includes quality controls throughout business processes. A proven QA methodology follows four key phases: Plan, Do, Check, and Act.

  • Plan - Determine the customer's expectations and requirements. Identify and document the processes and quality controls needed to satisfy customer’s expectations.
  • Do - Implement the established processes and quality controls—Prevent, Detect, and Correct—to meet customer expectations: Prevent defects from occurring, Detect potential defects early, and Correct any identified defects. Once these steps are completed, the product or service is handed over to the customer.
  • Check - Customer feedback is collected to evaluate whether the processes and quality controls are effectively meeting customer expectations. This helps assess the success of the product or service in fulfilling the customer's needs.
  • Act - Actions are taken to enhance the effectiveness and efficiency of the documented processes and quality controls to meet the customer’s expectations.

sections.title: Bangko Sentral Framework for IT Risk Supervision
sections.col1:
ITRM should be considered a component and integrated with the institutions’ risk management program.

The guidelines likewise provide practical plans to address risks associated with emerging trends in technology and growing concerns on cyber security.

Policy Statement

  • BSFIs employ advances in technology to sharpen business insights, enhance operational efficiencies, and deliver innovative financial products and services in line with emerging market trends and evolving client needs.
  • Technological developments also enable greater access to financial services that promote an inclusive and responsive digital financial ecosystem.
  • Social media platforms may further complicate matters as news of disruptions as well as customer complaints can spread at unprecedented speeds.
  • Cyber-threats and attacks confronting the financial services industry pose added risks that can undermine public trust and confidence in the financial system.
  • BSFIs should establish robust and effective technology risk management processes, governance structures, and cybersecurity controls to ensure that the benefits derived from technological innovations can be fully optimized without compromising financial stability, operational resilience, and consumer protection.
sections.col2:
Purpose and Scope

  • The enhanced guidelines aim to provide guidance in managing risks associated with use of technology.
  • The guidelines are based on international standards and recognized principles of international practice for ITRM and shall serve as Bangko Sentral’s baseline requirement for all BSFIs.
  • The framework covers different facets of ITRM, some of which are supplemented with detailed guidelines in Appendices 74, 75, 76, 77, 78 and 79.
  • Subject guidelines, including the Appendices 74, 75, 76, 77, 78 and 79, are not “one-size-fits-all” and implementation of these need to be risk-based and commensurate with size, nature and types of products and services and complexity of IT operations of the individual BSFIs.
  • BSFIs shall exercise sound judgment in determining applicable provisions relevant to their risk profile.

sections.title: Bangko Sentral Framework for IT Risk Supervision
sections.col1:
Appendices: IT Risk Management Standards and Guidelines

74 IT Audit “…audit program should address IT risk exposures throughout the organization, including the areas of IT management and strategic planning, IT operations, client/server architecture, local and wide-area networks, telecommunications, physical and information security, electronic products and services, systems development and acquisition, and business continuity planning”

75 Information Security “…enables BSFIs to remain competitive and relevant as the financial services industry moves towards digital innovation.”

76 Project Management/Development, Acquisition and Change Management “…enterprise-wide and ongoing approach should be formalized in the IT strategic plan to help ensure that all major IT projects are consistent with its overall strategic goals.”
sections.col2:
77 IT Operations “…necessitates the adoption of risk management processes that promote sound and controlled operation of IT environments to ensure that IT operations process and store information in a timely, reliable, secure, and resilient manner.”

78 IT Outsourcing/Vendor Management “…risks may be realized in a different manner than if the functions were inside resulting in the need for well-structured process to properly manage risks and ensure that the interest of customers will not be compromised.”

79 Electronic Banking, Electronic Payment, Electronic Money and Other Electronic Products and Services “…the rapid development of electronic capabilities carries risks as well as benefits and it is important that these risks are recognized and managed by BSFIs in a prudent manner to promote safe and secure e-services and operations.”

sections.title: Bangko Sentral Framework for IT Risk Supervision
sections.col1:
BSFIs are required to establish a robust ITRM system covering four key components:

IT Governance

  • Oversight and organization of IT functions
  • IT policies, procedures and standards
  • IT audit
  • Staff competence and training
  • Management Information Systems (MIS)
  • IT risk management function

Risk Identification and Assessment

  • Begins with the identification of the current and prospective IT risk exposures arising from the institution’s IT environment and related processes.
  • Once management understands the institution’s IT environment and analyzes the risk, it should rank the risks and prioritize its response.
  • Periodic risk assessment process should be done at the enterprise-wide level and an effective monitoring program for the risk mitigation activities should be manifested through mitigation or corrective action plans, assignment of responsibilities and accountability and management reporting.
sections.col2:
IT Controls Implementation

  • BSFI Management should implement satisfactory control practices that address the following as part of its overall IT risk mitigation strategy:
  • Information security
  • Project management/development and acquisition and change management
  • IT operations
  • IT outsourcing/Vendor management
  • Electronic banking, Electronic payments, Electronic money and other Electronic products and services

Risk Measurement and Monitoring

  • Performance vis-à-vis approved IT strategic plan
  • Performance benchmarks/service levels
  • Quality assurance/quality control
  • Policy compliance
  • External assessment program

sections.title: AFASA on Risk Management Systems and Controls to Protect Financial Accounts
sections.subheader: Anti-Financial Scamming Act (AFASA) was signed on July 20, 2024, and took effect on August 13, 2024
sections.col1:
Section 6. Responsibility to Protect Access to Client’s Financial Account

  • Institutions shall ensure that access to clients’ financial accounts is protected by adequate risk management systems and controls
  • Risk management systems and controls must be proportionate and commensurate to the nature, size and complexity of operations.
  • Institutions determined by the BSP to be compliant with the requirements of adequate risk management systems and controls shall not be liable for any loss or damage arising from the offenses under Sections 4 (Prohibited Acts) and Section 5 (Other Offenses).
  • Without prejudice to other liabilities under existing laws and consistent with BSP rules and regulations, institutions shall be liable for restitution of funds to the Account Owners for failure to employ adequate risk management systems and controls, or failure to exercise the highest degree of diligence in preventing loss or damage arising from the offenses under Section 4 and 5.
  • Conviction shall not be a prerequisite to the restitution of funds.

sections.title: AFASA on Risk Management Systems and Controls to Protect Financial Accounts
sections.col1:
Section 4. Prohibited Acts

The following acts shall constitute Financial Account scamming under this Act:

(a) Money Muling Activities. A person performing any of the followings acts for the purpose of obtaining, receiving, depositing, transferring, or withdrawing proceeds that are known to be derived from crimes, offenses, or social engineering schemes shall be considered as a money mule:

  • Using, borrowing or allowing the use of a Financial Account;
  • Opening a Financial Account under a fictitious name or using the identity or identification documents of another;
  • Buying or renting a Financial Account;
  • Selling or lending a Financial Account; or
  • Recruiting, enlisting, contracting, hiring, utilizing, or inducing any person to perform the acts mentioned in items 1 to 4 of this subsection.

(b) Social Engineering Schemes. A social engineering scheme is committed by a person who obtains sensitive identifying information of another person, through deception or fraud, resulting in unauthorized access and control over the person's Financial Account, by performing any of the following acts:

  • Misrepresenting oneself as acting on behalf of an Institution, or making false representations to solicit another person's sensitive identifying information; or
  • Using electronic communications to obtain another person's sensitive identifying information.

c) Economic Sabotage. The prohibited acts under Section 4(a) and (b) shall be considered as economic sabotage when committed under any of the following circumstances:

  • By a group of three (3) or more persons conspiring or confederating with one another;
  • Against three (3) or more persons individually or as a group;
  • Using a mass mailer; or
  • Through human trafficking.
sections.col2:
Section 5. Other Offenses

The following shall also constitute as offenses under this Act:

  • Willfully aiding or abetting in the commission of any of the offenses enumerated under Section 4;
  • Willfully attempting to commit any of the offenses enumerated under Section 4;
  • Opening a Financial Account under a fictitious name or using the identity or identification documents of another; or
  • Buying or selling a Financial Account.

sections.title: AFASA on Risk Management Systems and Controls to Protect Financial Accounts
sections.col1:
BSFIs should ensure adoption of the following key controls to protect financial accounts:

BSFIs which are determined compliant by the BSP shall not be liable for any loss or damage arising from the offenses under Section 4 and 5 of AFASA.

However, BSFIs shall be liable for the restitution of funds to Account Owners for the failure to employ adequate risk management systems and controls for failure to exercise the highest degree of diligence in preventing loss or damage arising from the said offenses.

  • Fraud Management Systems (FMS)
  • Infrastructure and security monitoring
  • Multi-factor Authentication (MFA)
  • Account owner enrollment and verification processes, and ongoing monitoring of customer account and transactions
  • Audit Trail
  • Cybersecurity tests and evaluations

sections.title: Financial Services Cyber Resilience Plan 2024-2029
sections.body:
Goal 1

This covers strategies to sharpen the industry’s capabilities to proactively respond to and recover from major cyber incidents.

Priority actions under this goal are:

D1:Establish baseline industry incident response plan

D2: Develop scenario-based incident response playbooks

D3: Conduct progressive industry-wide cyber testing exercise regime

D4: Explore setting up of an industry Security Operations Center (SOC)

Goal 2

This encompasses strategies to institutionalize and expand sharing of timely and actionable cyberthreat intelligence across the financial community, including coordination and collaboration with other industry stakeholders and the National CERT (CERT-PH).

Priority actions under this goal are:

A1:Expand and further enhance Bankers Association of the Philippines Cybersecurity Incident Database (BAPCID) as an industry sharing platform

A2: Strengthen and forge strategic partnerships in domestic and international for a

A3: Support the enactment of cyber-related legislative initiatives (e.g., Anti-Financial Account Scamming Act, Liberalization of Secrecy of Deposits, etc.)

Goal 3

This goal covers strategies to instill strong cybersecurity culture and enhance cybersecurity skills and capabilities in the financial services industry.

Key priority actions include:

S1: Develop and implement cyber education program for BSFI Board and Senior Management

S2: Regularly conduct Chief Information Security Officer (CISO)/cyber form and Annual Cybersecurity Summit

S3: Conduct cybersecurity roadshows for small and medium-sized financial institutions (FIs)

S4: Pursue holistic programs on cybersecurity skills and talent development

S5:Mainstream cyber education and awareness programs for financial clients.

Goal 4

This goal contains strategies to promote cybersecurity best practices and standards across cybersecurity domains.

Priority actions under this goal are:

H1: Complete policy reforms on digital security controls, Application Programming Interface (API) security, Cybersecurity Maturity Model (CMM) framework, and supply chain risk managemen

H2: Explore establishment of an Industry Cyber Innovation/Research Hub

H3: Conduct benchmarking exercises on cyber capabilities

sections.title: Module Summary

Now that you have completed this course, you should be able to:

  • Define project risk and identify various types of risks that may occur in a project.
  • Recognize the risk management process and explore tools and frameworks relevant to each step of the process.
  • Gain a full understanding of Quality Assurance and its benefits and importance in managing digital transformation projects, specifically in the Risk Monitoring phase.
  • Obtain knowledge on the existing Philippine regulations in risk management systems to get ahead of identifying and monitoring possible risks in projects.

sections.title: Module Completion
sections.subheader: Congratulations on completing the Project Risk Management module!
sections.body:
You've now developed a comprehensive understanding of the fundamental terms and concepts related to project risk management.

As you move forward, remember the various types of risks that may occur in a project as well as the importance of effectively utilizing the risk management process. Explore the various tools and frameworks that are relevant to each step of this process. In addition, keep in mind the significance of quality assurance and its advantages in managing digital transformation projects, as well as the regulations in the Philippines concerning risk management systems.

We hope this module has equipped you with the knowledge and confidence to tackle any project risks that may come your way.
